Description: Head of terracotta female figure. A head broken from a figure of a female beneficent demon of large size. The hair is arranged in formal parallel waves and is surmounted by a narrow tightly bound wreath. She has large ring-shaped earrings, pierced from front to back. The rear of the head has come away at the join and is lost. Hollow; two-piece mould. Micaceous brown Nile silt.
Curator's comments: BM Terracotta IV Comparanda (complete figures and heads). Close: Doetsch-Amberger 1987: 126, no. 257; Paul 1959: no. 310. Near: Allard Pierson Museum, Amsterdam, no. 7470; Bailey 1998a: 27, fig. 1:4 (= Bailey 2006a: 268, no. 9) from Mons Claudianus, context Trajanic or later, within the second century ad; Breccia 1934: no. 201; Fischer 1994: no. 966, dated middle to second half of third century ad; Kaufmann 1913: fig. 76:7 (the head only, which appears to be alien to its body); Petrie Museum uc48218 and uc48220, both from Memphis; Pons Mellado 1998: 111, 1981/1/198; Vogt 1924: pl. xcvii:2. Bibliog. Vassilika 1992: 271, no. 49; Cook 1995: 228.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3112)
